author: queglay
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

It would be very helpful to take this bashism - to be able to run commmands and define the env vars inline for those commands without them polluting the rest of the shell enviornment.
```
$env:MYVAR="something" someprocess.ps1
```
After running this we would not see $env:MYVAR in the environment in bash, and its very helpful.

Here is a discussion on stack overflow with various workarounds which are unfortunate.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1420719/powershell-setting-an-environment-variable-for-a-single-command-only

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> ```
> $env:MYVAR="something" someprocess.ps1
> ```
> 
> After running this we would not see $env:MYVAR in the environment in bash, and its very helpful.

Why ?  Why is it useful for "MyVar" to go away?

I read the SO post , which TBH is "All shells should work in all regards like the shell I know" and that is just tiresome. 

` $env:MYVAR="something"   ;  someprocess.ps1 `    
Works. but if `someprocess.ps1` relies on an environment variable it has been written incorrectly, programming 101 is pass your parameters as parameters don't leave them lying about in variables  -  that command should be
` someprocess.ps1 -MYPARAM  "something" ` 
 
What about EXEs which use a variable e.g.
```
$env:TF_VAR_Secret = "DontTell"   ; terraform  x y z
```
I might accidentally leave the secret in my environment,  but most of the time these variables aren't a problem. 
Is putting  `$env:TF_VAR_Secret = $null` for those few occasions a big problem? 
Usually if you have a secret it's something you either run it as a script or copy & paste a command line, so there wouldn't me a lot of extra typing.
